name: Beef and Egg Bowl (Tanindon)
description: Quick and delicious, this Beef and Egg Rice Bowl called Tanindon is comfort food at its best. With thinly sliced beef and eggs cooked in a savory-sweet sauce and served over steamed rice, you'll devour every bite! It's a speedy meal that you can make in 20 minutes!

video.name: Tanindon (Beef and Egg Rice Bowl) 他人丼
video.description:
Quick and delicious, this Beef and Egg Rice Bowl called Tanindon is comfort food at its best. With thinly sliced beef and eggs cooked in a savory-sweet sauce and served over steamed rice, you’ll devour every bite! It’s a speedy meal that you can make in 20 minutes!

RECIPE: https://www.justonecookbook.com/tanindon/

Ingredients:
½ onion (142 g, 5 oz for 2 servings)
2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
½ lb thinly sliced beef (chuck or rib eye) (or slice your own meat)
1 green onion/scallion
2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice (1½ rice cooker cups (180 ml x 1.5 = 270 ml) yields roughly 2 servings (3 US cups) for donburi; see how to cook short-grain rice with a rice cooker, a pot over the stove, an Instant Pot, or a donabe)

For the Seasonings
½ cup dashi (Japanese soup stock; click to learn more)
3 Tbsp soy sauce
2 Tbsp sake
2 Tbsp mirin
1 Tbsp sugar

For the Garnish
pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga)
shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) (optional; sprinkle for a spicy kick)

recipeIngredient: 2  large eggs (50 g each w/o shell)
½ lb thinly sliced beef (chuck or ribeye) ((or slice your own meat))
2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice ((typically 1⅔ cups (250 g) per donburi serving))
pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga)
shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) ((optional; sprinkle for a spicy kick))

recipeInstructions.text: Before You Start: For the steamed rice, please note that 1½ cups (300 g, 2 rice cooker cups) of uncooked Japanese short-grain rice yield 4⅓ cups (660 g) of cooked rice, enough for 2 donburi servings (3⅓ cups, 500 g). See how to cook short-grain rice with a rice cooker, pot over the stove, Instant Pot, or donabe.
recipeInstructions.name: Before You Start: For the steamed rice, please note that 1½ cups (300 g, 2 rice cooker cups) of uncooked Japanese short-grain rice yield 4⅓ cups (660 g) of cooked rice, enough for 2 donburi servings (3⅓ cups, 500 g). See how to cook short-grain rice with a rice cooker, pot over the stove, Instant Pot, or donabe.

recipeInstructions.text: Gather all the ingredients. I usually put the thinly sliced beef in the freezer for 10 minutes because it‘s a lot easier to cut semi-frozen meat.
recipeInstructions.name: Gather all the ingredients. I usually put the thinly sliced beef in the freezer for 10 minutes because it‘s a lot easier to cut semi-frozen meat.

itemListElement.text: Cut 1 green onion/scallion into thin slices.
itemListElement.name: Cut 1 green onion/scallion into thin slices.

itemListElement.text: Next, crack and beat 2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) in a small bowl.
itemListElement.name: Next, crack and beat 2 large eggs (50 g each w/o shell) in a small bowl.

itemListElement.text: Then, take out ½ lb thinly sliced beef (chuck or ribeye) from the freezer. Cut the sliced meat into pieces 3 inches (7.6 cm) wide.
itemListElement.name: Then, take out ½ lb thinly sliced beef (chuck or ribeye) from the freezer. Cut the sliced meat into pieces 3 inches (7.6 cm) wide.

itemListElement.text: In a large frying pan (do not turn on the heat yet), add ½ cup dashi (Japanese soup stock), 3 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp sake, 2 Tbsp mirin, and 1 Tbsp sugar. Mix to combine.
itemListElement.name: In a large frying pan (do not turn on the heat yet), add ½ cup dashi (Japanese soup stock), 3 Tbsp soy sauce, 2 Tbsp sake, 2 Tbsp mirin, and 1 Tbsp sugar. Mix to combine.

itemListElement.text: Next, add the onion slices and spread them throughout the pan, separating the onion layers.
itemListElement.name: Next, add the onion slices and spread them throughout the pan, separating the onion layers.

itemListElement.text: Then, add the meat on top of the onions. Separate the thin slices of beef so the meat covers the onions.
itemListElement.name: Then, add the meat on top of the onions. Separate the thin slices of beef so the meat covers the onions.

itemListElement.text: Cover the pan with a lid and start cooking over medium heat.
itemListElement.name: Cover the pan with a lid and start cooking over medium heat.

itemListElement.text: When the meat is cooked, skim off the scum and fat from the broth with a fine-mesh skimmer. Turn down the heat to simmer and continue cooking, covered, for 3–4 minutes.
itemListElement.name: When the meat is cooked, skim off the scum and fat from the broth with a fine-mesh skimmer. Turn down the heat to simmer and continue cooking, covered, for 3–4 minutes.

itemListElement.text: Slowly drizzle a thin stream of the beaten eggs over the simmering beef, placing your cooking chopsticks at the edge of the bowl with the eggs to control the flow. Do not mix the egg with the beef. Sprinkle the green onions on top and cook covered on medium-low heat until the egg is done to your liking (but don‘t overcook it). Usually, rice bowls with eggs in Japan are served while the egg is almost set but still runny. Remove from the heat.
itemListElement.name: Slowly drizzle a thin stream of the beaten eggs over the simmering beef, placing your cooking chopsticks at the edge of the bowl with the eggs to control the flow. Do not mix the egg with the beef. Sprinkle the green onions on top and cook covered on medium-low heat until the egg is done to your liking (but don‘t overcook it). Usually, rice bowls with eggs in Japan are served while the egg is almost set but still runny. Remove from the heat.

itemListElement.text: Divide 2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice into individual donburi rice bowls and put the beef and egg mixture on top. If you’d like, drizzle any remaining pan sauce on top. Top with pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga) and shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) (optional). Enjoy!
itemListElement.name: Divide 2 servings cooked Japanese short-grain rice into individual donburi rice bowls and put the beef and egg mixture on top. If you’d like, drizzle any remaining pan sauce on top. Top with pickled red ginger (beni shoga or kizami beni shoga) and shichimi togarashi (Japanese seven spice) (optional). Enjoy!

itemListElement.text: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days and in the freezer for a month.
itemListElement.name: You can keep the leftovers in an airtight container and store in the refrigerator for up to 3 days and in the freezer for a month.

review.reviewBody: Thank you, Nami for this ridiculously easy and tasty recipe! It worked perfectly and will now be on my list of things to cook on a busy week day.

First came "In a large frying pan (do not turn on the heat yet), add the dashi, soy sauce, sake, mirin, and 
ar. Mix to combine." Then came, "If you’d like, drizzle the remaining sauce on top. " where did the extra sauce come from? Recipe is a simple keeper. I'll repeat, thanks
Excellent recipe. So easy and the taste is so authentic! Reminded me of my childhood in Japan. :-)

Hi Naomi, many thanks for your kind message, I accidently got your web link nearly a year ago and love to follow your website since then. Your recipes make me interested in cooking Japanese dishes, the instructions are so simple and look easy to do. Many thanks again.
